description: From late Middle English, borrowed from Middle French agilité, from Latin agilitās, from agilis (“nimble, fleet, quick”), equivalent to agile +‎ -ity.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The quality of being agile; the power of moving the limbs quickly and easily; quickness of motion
examples: His superior agility countered his lack of strength.

entries.meaning: (countable) A faculty of being agile in body, mind, or figuratively.
